The Fort-12 is an attempt for recently-independent Ukraine (from August 1991) to create its own police pistol to replace the Soviet-era Makarov PM while still using the same 9x18 caliber. Designed in 1995 and developed in 1998 by Ukrainian firearms designer RPC Fort, this is a formidable pistol considered to be an upgrade of the PM itself. Although it may have reliability issues, especially due to the lack of a safe decocking facility, it compensates with accuracy, magazine size and ergonomics. This model comes with a threaded barrel, allowing the attachment of a suppressor.

The Fort-17 pistol is the latest development of the Ukrainian state owned FORT factory. It is a polymer framed modification of the earlier Fort-12 pistol. All the mechanisms and properties are almost identical between the two pistols. However, the Fort-17 is lighter than its predecessor and features a removable grip backstrap for better comfort.

The Fort-21.01 is a copy of the Jericho 941 manufactured by "RPC Fort", made after making a contract with "Israel Military Industries" in September 2009. Considering its relatively "new" status, especially in The Zone, it is a rather rare pistol, hence the price. It is modeled upon the CZ-75, in which case both can share their respective 16-round magazines. It uses 9x19 caliber instead of 9x18 unlike its older brothers, the Fort-12 and Fort-17.
